what is blood transfusion: Blood transfusion is a medical procedure where blood or blood components are given to a person through a vein. It is usually done to replace blood lost during surgery, injury, or disease.
types of blood groups: The main blood groups in the ABO and Rh system are: A+, A-, B+, B-, AB+, AB-, O+, and O-. They are based on the presence or absence of A/B antigens and the Rh factor on red blood cells.
difference between a+ and a- blood: A+ and A- both have A antigen on red blood cells, but A+ has the Rh factor while A- does not. A+ can receive A+, A-, O+, O- blood, while A- can receive only A- and O- safely.
what is hemoglobin: Hemoglobin is the iron-containing protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen from the lungs to the rest of the body and returns carbon dioxide back to the lungs.
what is rh factor: Rh factor is a protein that can be present on the surface of red blood cells. If you have it, you are Rh positive (e.g., A+, O+). If you donâ€™t, you are Rh negative (e.g., A-, O-).
what is universal donor: O negative (O-) blood is called the universal donor for red blood cells because it usually can be given to people of any ABO and Rh blood group in emergencies.
what is universal recipient: AB positive (AB+) blood is called the universal recipient for red blood cells because people with AB+ can receive blood from any ABO and Rh group.
what is plasma: Plasma is the liquid part of blood. It is mostly water and contains proteins, hormones, nutrients, and waste products. It helps carry cells and substances around the body.
what is blood smear: A blood smear is a lab test where a drop of blood is spread on a glass slide, stained, and examined under a microscope to look at the size, shape, and number of blood cells.
why is blood grouping important: Blood grouping is important to ensure safe blood transfusions, avoid dangerous reactions, and help in pregnancy care, organ transplantation, and some medical treatments.
